.
Also working on some new lower legs to make assembly abit easier.
.
Trying to stay in line with Games Workshop IP Policy. If any GW employee or representative wishes me to remove or alter any designs, let me know and I will comply with expediency. Below I’ve outlined how I tried to comply with their policies.
.
Overall - None of these are exact replicas. I tried to add abit of my own take on things or modification to the design. Ei kitbash it abit. Additionally, all models should just be used for painting practice. Practice messing up a paint job on a print, not your actual GW model.
.
Copyrights - I tried to make sure a “significant part” was not the same. Style, yes. Copied, no.
.
Trademark - I’ve removed all specific Trademarks. Ex: Aquila
Non-commercial - I’m making no money from this
.
Professional Distribution - I’m not a professional artist, using any of these as a portfolio advertisement. Just a hobbiest tinkering
.
Damage our brand - Not doing that. GW IP is a pretty cool universe. Hence the reason I wanted to make models that “live” in it.
.
Make it clear you’re doing it unofficial - I’m doing this UNOFFICIALLY.
.
Use trademarks appropriately - I tried to remove all trademarks
.
Derivative Works - I believe most of these models would fall under derivative works, two are three models might not, but I think most do.
.
Non-commercial recasting and 3D printing - I have not scanned any of GW’s IP.

author: outofstep

description.text:
If you've broken you broken the loop on your water bottle (in our case it was melted in the dishwasher) this thing can provide a replacement. Use the customizer to size the inner loop. The smaller loop will fit a standard key ring type carabiner. The loop is only 1 mm thick so this prints fast and easy with just a small amount of filament. I used ABS, but I suspect PLA will work (although it may be a little less strong).
UPDATED: The original design broke when my daughter used it so I've made the design stronger. Let's see how this one survives.

author: outofstep

title: Polyhedron Facets ( revised, parametric )
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This thing includes a revised parametric script for generating polygonal facets for use in polyhedra. Several possible facets have been rendered. I know that the triangular, square, and pentagonal facets presented here are sufficient for building a wide range of shapes. Thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5028 extends this set with more types of facets, including spoke-like and polygonal facets for all shapes. I've been wanting to create a very generic snap-together set of forms for MakerBot for some time. It would be awesome to have an algorithm that generates a queue of forms to slowly grow a very large procedurally generated object. This is a revision of things http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4893 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4899, and an attempt to create a compatible set of snap-together primitives for building geometric forms. Thing 4893 set too large a scale to print pentagonal facets. Thing 4899 had a mathematical error which caused the different faces to be incompatible. This revision corrects that error.

Look up a polyhedron design, and print out the appropriate facets. Clean, and assemble. As long as you print out as many [+] snaps as [-] snaps, these pieces have a habit of coming together. These pieces can also be assembled into amorphous but rigid forms.
These pieces are snap-compatible with things 4893 and 4899, and shapes like the truncated tetrahedron (an octahedron with 50/50 triangles from two different scales), cuboctahedron, and icosidodecahedron, can be built by mixing triangles from one version with the appropriate polygons from another version. This creates a rigid solid that can serve as an interface for two different sets of piece sizes, if you are building some sort of amorphous structure.

comments.text: An extension of this set of pieces would be a set of pieces for constructing a large object out of arbitrary small facets. For example, a mesh model could be refined  in sufficient small triangles. A script could generate the .STL files for a snap-together version of each facet. Then, the whole thing could be printed and assembled as a puzzle. The space on the interior of the facets is flexible, so that could be used to add other features : more snaps, mounting points for hardware. Maybe we can make more of mendel fastener-free. The snaps are currently designed to rotate freely as hinges, but structural applications might require a high-friction snap ( easily adjusted in the script ).

title: Adjustable Wheel Chair for Dog (Branco Project)

description.text:
Can be adjusted for different sizes by screwing/unscrewing the parts and once adjusted just cut the endless screw tips and its done. Might need soldering of the endless screw to the bolts to improve strength.
Can be used with bicycle training wheels or with big printed Wheel. See pictures.
Dog's and Wheel Chair Story here: http://3dprint.com/18651/3d-printed-dog-wheelchair/

Big Wheel - Printed with PLA. Insert a GLCODE @pause instruction before the first layer of the top of the axis so you can put the ball bearing in place and let the printer finish printing the wheel with the ball bearing inside it. After putting the ball bering in place, put the extra ring printed on the first layer on top of it so the subsequent layer sticks more easily.
Example: for a 0,3mm layer, at the end of the layer 37 add:
G1 X0 Y0
@pause
this will move nozzle away and pause the printer so you can insert the ball bearing. An alert will show in Repetier with a button to "continue printing".
Tire - Printed with Flexible Filament but you can just use hight tension rubber tape around the wheel.
Can use bicycle training wheels instead of big wheel like in the picture.
Will include Instructions for the Fabric Bed soon.
1 meter of Velcro to fix the chair on the Dog using the "Velcro Holder" Part. (See Last Photo). Chest and Top Velcro. Threaded Rod Diameter: 8mm + 14 nuts.
2 Bell Bearings External Diameter: 26mm.

The body and neck of this electric guitar were 3d printed on a Flash Forge. The neck is assembled with two carbon fiber tubes set in epoxy in place of a traditional truss rod. The neck was further strengthened by infiltrating the infill areas of the print with epoxy resin. The neck-through body design allows the maker to print the body of their choice without changing the configuration of the core. The first one printed plays, although not well, so this should be considered a work in progress and maker beware. I designed this as a "could it be done" exercise more than anything. It has several interesting features: A 3d printed neck with carbon fiber reinforcement. Epoxy infiltration as a strengthening technique. A 3d printed fingerboard with printed slots for fretwire. I wrote an openSCAD script to generate fretboards of any scale length. 3d printed inlay on the headstock and fingerboard. These could be done as dual extrusions, but it is easier to print them separately and assemble. The neck and body section are assembled using 3mm filament stubs for alignment. After having completed this project I can say that at this point it is fairly pointless to print the neck as far superior stock quitar necks are available for less than the cost of the materials, but that was't the point. The body design requires too much support to be satisfactory when printed on an FDM machine. We talked about this thing and a whole lot more about 3d printing on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/ 3/16/15 Update. Swapped out new peghead veneer file.

title: Bed leveling mount for MSC Drop Indicator on Makergear M2

description.text: A mount custom made for a makergear M2 to  attach to a drop indicator for bed leveling.

Just rotate fans up, and tighten rear knurled screw on hot end. No tools needed. Very quick and easy. Indicator is available at mscdirect.com
and is ITEM #91942961. It's only 19 bucks! You will need to cut the heads off of a 6-32 screw and a 1/4-20 screw as well. The holes in the printed parts are designed to let these screws self tap. The 6-32 may need to be drilled up a few thousandths of an inch. You want .125 as the OD thread of a 6-32 is .135. Gives a little bite into the plastic as it self taps. You know wut I'm sayin'? Try to get screws to self tap straight. You could drill a little closer to size of screw for easy self threading, and use a few drops of super glue on last few threads.
Please upload any pics of makes!

title: Mini Kossel Basic Dual Extruder Effector

description.text:
Update
======
I updated the gallery pictures to show the new print of this -- the original effector body was an older verison which was slightly thinner. Also please note the probe tower was accidentally printed in reverse due to incorrect wiring but I think it should be possible to deploy the probe automatically if it's printed right (I will validate that soon). If someone finds otherwise I can look into changing the positions of the various mounting holes to make it work better. Please post any feedback in the comments!
Features
=======
This thing is a basic dual extruder effector for Mini Kossel. It was derived from the Kossel source SCAD with modifications to accommodate 2 hot ends. The modifications are the following:

  • Thicker effector for added strength

  • Wider center circle diameter to accommodate 2 hot ends side by side (all important Delta measurements remain the same so the same carriages can be used)

  • More mounting holes to make up for those obstructed by the new hot end positions

  • New fan bracket / groove mount designed for 30mm fan, which attempts to minimize air blown directly on the heater blocks

  • New probe tower with reduced footprint to work with new mounting holes

  • Optional M5 thread OR non-threaded holes for NPT 1/8" / M10 push fit adapters (I use NPT pipe tap which is cheap and easy to find in USA)

  • Optional cone supports to prevent warping of critical cone overhangs
    • I have been printing with various prototypes of this on my machine for a few weeks now. I think the design is at least stable enough now to be considered "work in progress"

Due to high temperatures I would recommend printing in HIPS, ABS or some other similarly temperature-resistant material. I have found excellent results printing with HIPS perimeters (4-5 layers @ 0.35mm nozzle) and PLA infill (0.5mm nozzle, 25% honeycomb). The PLA infill helps enhance platform adhesion and seems to greatly reduce warping / shrinkage compared to solid HIPS.
All mounting hardware should be the same as the standard Kossel -- that is M3 for everything except the push fit which can use the original M5 OR use a larger non-threaded hole for other types of push fit connectors. I have added nut traps on the fan bracket to ease assembly.
If you are curious about my hot end configuration, I am using MakerGear-style groove mount hot ends from RP1 Labs. These ends normally don't have great heat dissipation but I found some 8MM laser diode heatsinks on ebay which I cut into smaller pieces with a band saw and press fit with a bench vise. I have also tested this effector with standard J-Head hot ends and the result is identical. I use the RP1 ends because they have interchangeable nozzles and heater barrels so I can switch filament sizes easily.

Have you ever looked at a tube you have lying around the house and thought, "Man, I'd like to make a rocket out of that!" Well now, you can!  
This is a simple collection of OpenSCAD files that allow you to input the dimensions of a tube(inner and outer radius) and watch as OpenSCAD creates the 3D model.  This collection has 3 main rocket parts:  
Nosecone:  The nosecone file creates a simple conical nosecone  
Coupler:  The coupler creates a coupler so that you can stick multiple tubes together  
Fincan:  The fincan file allows you to set the radius of the motor you want to use (default is an 18mm motor) as well as the fin shape and position

To make a nosecone, coupler or fincan that fits for a specific tube that you want to use as the airframe, simply change the variables in the respective .scad files with OpenSCAD. Make sure your fins are the right size or you might not have a stable flight!...but that's up to you. You can model your rocket in OpenRocket to check if it will be stable. Download OpenSCAD here: http://www.openscad.org/
Download OpenRocket here: http://openrocket.sourceforge.net/

title: Compound Bow Center Shot Laser Alignment Tool

description.text:
This assembly is used to help set the center shot on a compound bow.
To complete this assembly the following is needed:
Hardware:
4 - 10-24 countersunk head x 1.5" in length
2 - M6 Washers
1 - M6 Nylock Nut
2 - M6 Standard Nuts
2 - 10-24 Nuts
1- M6 Hex Head bolt 60mm to 70mm in length
Printed Parts:
1 - Riser_Mount.stl ( 1 nut is inserted during this print)
1 - Laser_Clamp_Outer.stl
1 - M6 Knob ( 1 nut is inserted during this print)
1 - Laser_Clamp_Base.stl (2 nuts are inserted during this print)
2 - 10_24_Keeper_Washer.stl
4 - 10_24_Knob.stl
You will also need to supply a laser pointer. I recommend a decent laser pointer and not a cat toy type laser that costs a few bucks as from testing the alignment\lens on those are not good.
A few of these components require the nuts be inserted during the prints by pausing @zpos and then inserting the nuts and continuing the print. I would use a gcode viewer to find the last layer height the boundary of the nut pockets are printed at and then set the printer to pause at that height so you can insert the nuts in.
Once all the parts are printed:
(1) Obtain the hardware mentioned and print all the necessary parts
(2) Screw the 10-24 countersunk screws into the 10-24 knobs
(3) Assemble the Laser Clamp Base part to the M6 bolt using M6 washers on either side and the M6 Nylock nut. Tighten the lock nut just enough so the clamp can still rotate but is not loose on the shaft.
(4) Insert 2 of the 10-24 knob\screw assemblies into the riser mount part and then use the keeper washers on the opposite side to keep the screws from falling out all the time. The bolts should be inserted so the washers are in the pockets in the plastic part so the mount can sit flush on the bow riser.
(5) Thread the M6 bolt with laser clamp base into the riser mount and then thread the M6 Knob on the opposite side.
(6) Install the outer laser clamp to the laser clamp base using the remaining 2 10-24 knobolt assemblies.
(7) insert laser pointer and tighten clamp so laser does not move.
To use:
(1) Install on bow riser at the sight mounting holes
(2) Adjust laser position by threading the m6 bolt into or out of the riser mount so the laser aligns with the center of the string.
(3) Tighten down m6 knob to keep it in position and then recheck the alignment and adjust as necessary.
(4) Laser can then be used to check alignment of arrow shaft to bow string.
Accuracy will depend upon laser used and accuracy of the printed parts so keep that in mind during use.

(It stands up fine with the raft removed but I figured that having a larger footprint was safer for anything with actual fire).  Very straightforward and simple print.  I'm not sure why the stl file seems to be imaged backwards here - it prints fine.

remixed_from.author: thirdhorizon
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Flexible Filament Direct Drive Extruder

title: Printrbot Direct-Drive Extruder - i3 compatible, 1.75/3mm filament, mk7/8 - all parts

description.text:
UPDATED Feb 6, 2015: I changed the built in support material, added a recess that will fit an e3d-v6 better (the retainer for the ptfe tubing). I also made slight tweaks to the i3, 1.75, mk8 version's nut traps. I'll reupdate with i2,simple metal, mk7 and 3mm versions soon. Also, I made some changes to the fan shroud attachment, and the actual shroud itself that's working really well. UPDATED Jan 9, 2015: I added my mount and shroud for a fan (intended to cool the plastic coming out of the nozzle, works with i3). I included the solidworks assembly that I used to position the fan optimally. It is adjustable and fully modifiable. I've added the .step files to make it more adjustable without solidworks. I've also added an extended e3d 40mm fan shroud that I made when trying to use an e3d v5 on my i2 (for any extruder in general, but also with my i2, 3mm, MK8 extruder) and I couldn't fit the e3d hotend cooling fan under the i2 carriage. Easily modifiable to make it for a 30mm fan. UPDATED Jan 6, 2015: I've added an experimental way to finely adjust the height of the extruder mount with m3 nuts and bolts. Beta for now, but I plan on testing them some time this month. I've also added MK7 versions of the extruder for i2 and i3 printers (or for any printer that secures the extruder with these standard hole locations) but they're untested for now as well. UPDATED Nov 1, 2014: I've added better supports, (i2 mount works now) height adjustment for dual extrusion and a possible fan mount. Check them out. I loved the extruder on my PB simple metal and want to use a similar one on my other printers. I also liked one of the mods that made it better at printing flexible filaments (thing 403438). I went ahead and redesigned it from scratch in solidworks, sorry no openscad for now, (maybe in the future, it should be simple) It has all three parts and uses a few different parts than the original.
The nut holder is a hex hole instead of just the groove (D=7+0.4mm diameter to fit a standard m4 nut, but you could change this to 7.7+0.4mm to fit the original nut. I used an m4 bolt and 624 bearing (4mm axle, 13mm diameter, 5mm thickness). I tweaked the arm to fit with these, but these are more common than the 625 bearing they use. The axle/pin is similar to what they use but may not be directly swappable. Everything is positioned for 1.75mm filament, but should be lined up so that you can just drill it out to 3-3.175.
I made variations for a mk7 (14mm cutout for 12.5mm diameter gear with 11.56mm hob diameter) and mk8 (10mm cutout for a 9mm diameter gear with a 6.9mm hob diameter). The MK8's smaller diameter necessitated moving a few features over by 2mm (11.56-6.9=4.66/2=2.33~2mm) I also put in a recess so a grub screw can stick out a little bit without interfering. This can be attached to the PB SM with stock screws by inserting nuts into the nut traps. It can also be used on an i3 by printing the appropriate part and mounting as any other extruder. All the parts should be symmetrical (I think?) and you can set up dual extrusion by putting them side by side (just enough clearance. That's all I can think of for now, it works at the moment, but it is a work in progress.

Just a fun little case.
I often use my phone to watch movies while traveling, but I always have to hold it or prop it up on something. With this lego case, all you need is to throw a few legos in your bag and you're set.
Experiment with placement and number of legos to battle glare. Who knows what other useful possibilities you may come up with for this case.

Print.
Snap in your phone.
Snap on the LEGOS. Enjoy! A note on printing: I have found that it is easiest to print on it's side with the volume cutout on the top (as it is in the last pic I have uploaded). It is quite difficult to remove the support from in between the "nubs"( if printed "nubs down") so the legos fit flat and snug. It's also difficult to completely remove support from the entire inside surface (if printed "nubs up"), at least for me it was.
Let me know if you have success or failure in different orientations.

This is a candleholder fitting exactly for the "rechaud" type candle

This candleholder exactly fits for rechaud candles (14mm diameter, 16mm height). As for the file, the walls are the thinnest possible (0.4mm), so the lighting effect is at its best. Use transparent (colourless) PLA or at least translucent colours (light blue or lemon yellow work very fine as well). When using it, first light the candle and then put it gently into the cup (to prevent wall damage by flickering or while using matches or lighter if the candle is alredy inside).
And be creative by inserting small pieces of PLA of several coulours into the bowden tube - this will give you "rainbow patterns" on the candleholder!

title: Nightmare before Christmas - Jack Skellington with Glowing Pumpkins

description.text:
This Model is a Halloween Special Edition!

  • Nightmare before Christmas - Jack Skellington with Glowing Pumpkins!

    • Print Model
    • Print him alone, the full set or just the pumpkins
    • Hack a Tealight Candle and add wires to a Yellow LED with some wire
    • Hot Glue the LED inside the Pumpkin and the wires coming from tealight to prevent disconnection
      Can be printed without support!

  • See Instructions for Printing Details

  • Check out our other designs!

  • Designed by Westley Harrell

    • Don't want to miss our next Thing? Like our Facebook Page to stay updated!
      https://www.facebook.com/pages/3D-Customization-Company-LLC/476600689078434

• Bust
    • Printed with no support using Black ABS
    • 0% - Infill
    • .15 - Layer Height
    • 2 - Shells
  • Arms
    • Printed with no support using Clear ABS
    • 0% - Infill
    • .20 - Layer Height
    • 1 - Shell
  • Tealight Hookup
    • Cut bottom of Jacks arm and the top of the pumpkin off
    • Solder wires to LED
    • Feed LED through the top of the pumpkin
    • Solder in new LED through the top of the tealight
    • Glue Arm to the top of the tealight when finished
    • Wait for glue to dry then paint
      Look at the collage photo to see more!

Calibration print.
Dimension compensation test.

Irreplaceable if you plan to print parts friction fit :)

comments.text:
AH. I figured out how these things were supposed to work.
One set is for compensating for if your printer is printing too big. The other set is for printing smaller.
Anyway,
the ones with holes in the middle for some reason, has the tab grow
bigger, while the slot grows smaller by .1mm. The 0 position is 10mm.
The ones that are solid in the middle has the tab grow smaller while the slot grows bigger by .1mm. The 0 position is 4mm.
I don't know why these aren't made so one set does both + and - values. Eg: a set of 9.8, 9.9, 10.0, 10.1, 10.2
No idea why both sets are different sizes from each other either. It'd be much more useful if both sets fit with each other.

title: RAR Print - Open source, low-cost, photopolymer 3D printer

description.text:
RAR Print is 3d printer that you can made by printing almost all it's parts and use same parts from old CD|DVD ROMs.
TIP: Write youre questions :) I Try to explain all moments
Quick specs:
Printer Dimensions (LxWxH): 290 mm X 190 mm X 200 mm
Print head: UV diode + CD|DVD drive optic system
Build Volume (LxWxH): 80 mm x 80 mm x 80 mm
Minimum Layer-height: 10 Microns (0.01 mm)
Precision: Same as in CD|DVD Disk
Board: Arduino Mega 2560
__NEWS_____
07/08/2016 NEW FDM 3d printer
RAR Print Double - unic 3D printer with two build platforms http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1700571 11/26/2015 Now I am experimenting with DLP 3d printer and custom photopolymers. Results you can see here:
https://yadi.sk/a/2GeOJ0HEkZXzp 01/25/2015 Hi world! :) Sorry for the silence. I got married 31 october ^_^ . Then was travelling around Siberia Mountains ( Altay region). And I started new work at Tomsk city. So about RAR Priner project: I get my:
Ramps 1.4 boards
Old RAR printer prototype printed parts
and many other parts which will help with project On google docs available newest instructions for assembling 3D printer RAR print: https://docs.google.com/document/d/152UdYUsXrQIEFH6rQjsgM5scn52KM0iCF9XoKVdYWSE/edit?usp=sharing Mikhail Shevchenko 11/17/2014 Hi ! ) :) Very soon experiments will begins. Good guys from Bestfilament company gave to me Arduino MEGA 2560. I still waiting for RAMPS 1.4 and Pololu drivers A4988. Photo below:
old DVD ROM , uv led, Arduino MEGA 2560 and small dvd rom from notebook. http://vk.com/rarprint?z=photo-72484195_343361200%2Falbum-72484195_00%2Frev 10/16/2014 Thank you to all interested in the project! Thanks for the feedback, it helps a lot.
I decided to create a 3D printer, and show how you too can do it at home. I will be blogging on YouTube. And duplicate the information here.
Remember, I'm doing a project in their spare time. Hence on any clear time frames there is no question.
Soon will show you how to make this 3D printer with your hands. The project is free and open.
Stay tuned for updates! :) My youtube channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2e9UDoku9wXszHs8dqu_8w
Articles about RAR print :
http://3dprint.com/18601/rar-sla-3d-printer/ (English)
http://habrahabr.ru/post/240039/ (Russian)
http://www.3ders.org/articles/20141014-russian-man-creates-a-sla-3d-printer-from-old-cd-dvd-drives.html (English)
http://3druck.com/drucker-und-produkte/rar-print-open-source-sla-3d-drucker-aus-cddvd-rom-laufwerken-fuer-e200-5525011/ (German)
http://i-maker.jp/rar-print-5466.html (Japan)

You'l need:
-2 kg of PLA plastic ( parts shown were printed using it)
-300x400 mm - organic glass ( orange)
-5 or 10 /// CD|DVD - ROMs ( with work stepper drives )
-1 dvd ROM optic system + 1 UV LED ( Ultraviolet diode) Characteristics of UV diode may be any ( ~400 nm light wave, and power 100 -1000 mW) it depend what photopolimer you want to use.It installed instead laser diod into dvd ROM optic system
  • Arduino Mega 2560
  • Shield for CD|DVD ROM drives
  • 5 CD|DVD ROM step motors drivers ( Example A4988)
  • wires and bus
  • Glass or plastic reservour ( For Makerjuice Photopolymer)
  • simple current and voltage regulator for UV Print head
  • Customized Marlin
    Attention: All printable parts oriented not correct to 3D printing. You must orient it before printing.Also you can chop parts into some pieces and print them ( If you have limited build volume into your 3D printer).

Hello,

comments.text: This is not what open-source is. To be open-source, you cannot forbid commercial use. It is a technical, "official" deffinition with 10 points to comply, as I have quoted here. If you say it is open-source and you use the "NC" clause, you are misleading people.

comments.author: Patola

comments.text: I might. I free all my projects, code and videos under open source licenses and I only get involved in open-source projects too. As a frantic open-source fan, nothing puts me off more than a "NC" clause, it means that commercial use, one of the main levers for making a project go right, is tightly limited, to the point of being stuck.

This is to fix a partly broken school bag (but might be used for any bag of similar size and material

This thing I created because my daughter's school bag was partly broken and instead of waiting to have it totally broken (and buy a new one), I hope this support will hold it together well.
If you print it out in 1:1 size, the screw holes fit exactly with the M3 screws you might have left from your Ultimakter building pack :-)
As the initial printing of the screwholes caused trouble (the fan wind blew them away), I added a slight closing layer which you must hole-punch before using the thing.
For the two outermost screws you need two M3 nuts, for the other six of them you need no nuts - you just screw them through the T-sized part (from inside the bag) through the back, into the small tubes of the rectangle-sized part. As you might see on the picture, the parts bent while printing - I have no solution for that, but in the end this had no effect on the practical use. But if you got a solution how to prevent them from bending please post it here.

comments.author: neoteric

comments.text: Thingiverse will let you upload your Sketchup file (which you should always do), but doesn't have a way of rendering it. I have a list of great Sketchup plugins - some of which will let you export to an STL which is printable and can be rendered by Thingiverse. Definitely consider using a different license (something like CC or others) and uploading the original design files so others can upload pictures of your Thing and help make improvements.
comments.author: MakerBlock

comments.text: Never used SketchUp, but you might have a look at http://ArtOfIllusion.orgArtOfIllusion.org - very nice software, with plugins that let it import and export to various formats, including STL which is what most of the 3D printers will accept (Thingiverse renders them automatically too). I use that for everything I do.

title: RCExplorer Tricopter custom landing gear
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Custom landing gear for RCExplorer Tricopter V3. Not as durable as the original, but useful while waiting for spare parts to arrive from David :-) Be aware: The original design does not in-corporate the "mechanical fuse" of David Windeståls design (zip ties breaking). There is a risk that a twisting force will break your booms on inpact. To minimize boom breakage, use the mechanical fuse version (MF) Buy the original Tricopter and carbon landing gear from http://www.RCExplorer.se

Front landing gear and motor mounts are attached to 10 mm square carbon fiber booms with M3x18 hex bolts.
Rear landing gear is clicked on and secured with a zip tie. For low impact on your booms, use the Mechanical Fuse versions (MF)
Glue the top and bottom parts with CA to create a "weak" spot.

author: Motorpixiegimbals

description.text:
Kids Toothpaste Roller
13-Oct-14 added the transformer -
14-Oct-14 added the forzen

This is a three blade wind turbine.  Just connect to a small motor and you can get up to around 1.4 volts in a good wind current.  It can double as a miniature fan, if you connect the motor up to a battery instead.  This is my first finished design for Thingiverse!

There are two parts to be printed, blades and a holder hub. The blades print vertically, as does the hub. You have to print 3 blades for this project. After printing, the blades snuggly fit into the holder hub (and could be glued for a stronger finish). The .stl files should be ready to print for a Makerbot. I found that on mine, rotating the orientation of the blades can affect how they turn out, because of where skeinforge starts and stops extruding for each layer, so I have them turned as best printed from mine using skeinforge 7. I designed it all using OpenSCAD. The nice thing with the blades is that I have created a bunch of variables that users can modify - so you can take my .scad file, and easily tweak the blades to be: longer or shorter, more/less curved, thicker and thinner, and wider/sleeker. Then just recompile and print! This uses a .dxf file created from Inkscape to provide the general blade shape and uses the linear_extrude function to convert the 2d representation of the blade into a 3d shape. Quite fun. To make .dxf files from .svg files, use pstoedit. I've included my makefile to show how this works. (1) References:

A little Box to make a smoker.
Add a 4W 30hom resistance inside with the contacts protected with thermal resistant silicon tube.
Wrap glass fiber around the resistance and in contact with the bottom of the box.
I plan to add it during print. Paraffin oil (or smoke liquid) will climb the glass fiber and come in contact with the resistance.
With 12V the resistance will burn the oil making smoke.
A 40x40 fan will force the smoke on the exit tube. Mk1 was a test
MK2 was made with plastic box but the oil leaks from the lid.
MK3 was 3D printed with flat top was impossible to print.
Mk4 is made to be more easy to print.

title: Customizable Halloween Flashlight Projector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is a fun way to encourage your kids to be safe this Halloween with the flashlight projector! Instead of just a regular beam of light you can be lead around while Trick-or-Treating by a cute ghost, witch, cat, or bat! Fully customizable with 5 different designs and the ability to fit any flashlight (or adapted to fit on a home spotlight to project on your house) and adapt the focal length to give you a sharper projection further away.
The included STLs are made to fit the mini Cree LED flashlight here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006E0QAFY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The largest beam diameter and longest barrel and cone lengths will give the sharpest projection the furthest distance away depending on what you can fit in your printer and want to carry around.
No special printing instructions except you can use very low fill since the walls are relatively thin. You can just add an extra perimeter instead of using higher infill and it should print in ~40 minutes even in the larger sizes.
For phone use I would recommend about 8mm barrel diameter or smaller to fit around the LED light for the camera flash and 25-30mm beam diameter for best results without it being too big.

description.text: Want to make your brochures light up?  Try using this LED lighted brochure rack.  There are 4 tiered racks and the widest space at the bottom measures 140mm (brochures should be at least this wide).

Easy. Print one of each file, I used 20% infill w/ 2 perimeters. The BatteryHolder file will require support material.
Run 2 wires through the tunnels on both verticalStand files. Solder LED to the front and leave 3-4" extra wire in the back.
When using a 9V battery, create a series circuit with both LED's and a 180 Ohm resistor to drop the rest of the voltage in the circuit. Other batteries might require a different resistor value depending on the supply voltage. The LED lights press easily back into the hole. Plug in and enjoy having your brochures in the spotlight!!! PS. With a 9V battery, the lights have already stayed on for over 3 days!
